text.b: 2.6 acres located on Base Line Road, approximately
1000 feet east of Towne Avenue in the City of
Brian Desatnik, Housing and Redevelopment Manager
Currently RS 10,000; following the General Plan
conformity action the zoning will be RM 3,000.

page.text: The applicant proposes to develop a 45-unit multi-family residential development for low and very low-
income residents on Base Line Road approximately 1000 feet east of Towne Avenue in the City of
Claremont (A vicinity map, aerial photo and preliminary site plan are provided as Figures 1, 2 and 3
The site is currently vacant except for an abandoned, circular water reservoir that is 107 feet in
diameter. The I-210 Freeway abuts the site directly to the south and an Edison substation directly to
The area in the vicinity of the site consists of commercial and residential uses. To the north of the
proposed development across Base Line Road are single-family homes, to the east is a Southern
California Edison substation, to the west is vacant land used as a strawberry field and to the south is
The City of Claremont’s General Plan was adopted on November 14, 2006. The new General Plan
designates the project site as Residential 15. The new land use designation allows for multi-family
housing. The City is in the process of completing Citywide zone changes to make all current zoning
designations consistent with the new General Plan. Once completed, the new zoning designation for
the project site will be RM 3,000. The zone change will be adopted prior to the action on this

text.b: Single-Family Residential (Los Angeles County and City of Claremont, RS 13,000)

page.text: Other public agencies whose approval is required (e.g., permits, financing approval, or
Caltrans (if roadway improvements within Caltrans jurisdiction are required)
The environmental factors checked below would be potentially affected by this project, involving at
least one impact that is a "Potentially Significant Impact" as indicated by the checklist on the following
DETERMINATION (To be completed by the Lead Agency):
On the basis of this initial evaluation:
I find that the proposed project COULD NOT have a significant effect on the environment, and
a NEGATIVE DECLARATION will be prepared.
I find that although the proposed project could have a significant effect on the environment,
there will not be a significant effect in this case because revisions in the project have been
made by or agreed to by the project proponent. A MITIGATED NEGATIVE DECLARATION
I find that the proposed project MAY have a significant effect on the environment, and an
I find that the proposed project MAY have a "potentially significant" or "potentially significant
unless mitigated" impact on the environment, but at least one effect 1) has been adequately
analyzed in an earlier document pursuant to applicable legal standards, and 2) has been
addressed by mitigation measures based on the earlier analysis as described on attached
sheets. An ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT REPORT is required, but it must analyze only the
effects that remain to be addressed.
I find that although the proposed project could have a significant effect on the environment,
because all potentially significant effects (a) have been analyzed adequately in an earlier EIR
or NEGATIVE DECLARATION pursuant to applicable standards, and (b) have been avoided
or mitigated pursuant to that earlier EIR or NEGATIVE DECLARATION, including revisions or
mitigation measures that are imposed upon the proposed project, nothing further is required.
1) A brief explanation is required for all answers except "No Impact" answers that are adequately supported by
the information sources a lead agency cites in the parentheses following each question. A "No Impact"
answer is adequately supported if the referenced information sources show that the impact simply does not
apply to projects like the one involved (e.g. the project falls outside a fault rupture zone). A "No Impact"
answer should be explained where it is based on project-specific factors as well as general standards
(e.g. the project will not expose sensitive receptors to pollutants, based on a project-specific screening
2) All answers must take account of the whole action involved, including off-site as well as on-site, cumulative
as well as project-level, indirect as well as direct, and construction as well as operational impacts.
3) Once the lead agency has determined that a particular physical impact may occur, then the checklist
answers must indicate whether the impact is potentially significant, less than significant with mitigation, or
less than significant. "Potentially Significant Impact" is appropriate if there is substantial evidence that an
effect is significant. If there are one or more "Potentially Significant Impact" entries when the determination
is made, an EIR is required.
4) "Negative Declaration: Less Than Significant With Mitigation Incorporated" applies where the incorporation
of mitigation measures has reduced an effect from "Potentially Significant Impact" to a "Less than
Significant Impact." The lead agency must describe the mitigation measures, and briefly explain how they
reduce the effect to a less than significant level (mitigation measures from Section XVII, "Earlier Analyses,"
5) Earlier analyses may be used where, pursuant to the tiering, program EIR, or other CEQA process, an
effect has been adequately analyzed in an earlier EIR or negative declaration. Section 15063(c)(3)(D). In
this case, a brief discussion should identify the following:
a) Earlier Analyses Used. Identify and state where they are available for review.
b) Impacts Adequately Addressed. Identify which effects from the above checklist were within the scope of
and adequately analyzed in an earlier document pursuant to applicable legal standards, and state
whether such effects were addressed by mitigation measures based on the earlier analysis.
c) Mitigation Measures. For effects that are "Less than Significant with Mitigation Measures Incorporated,"
describe the mitigation measures, which were incorporated or refined from the earlier document and the
extent to which they address site-specific conditions for the project.
6) Lead agencies are encouraged to incorporate into the checklist references to information sources for
potential impacts (e.g. general plans, zoning ordinances). Reference to a previously prepared or outside
document should, where appropriate, include a reference to the page or pages where the statement is
7) Supporting Information Sources. A source list should be attached, and other sources used or individuals
contacted should be cited in the discussion.
8) This is only a suggested form, and lead agencies are free to use different formats; however, lead agencies
should normally address the questions from this checklist that are relevant to a project's environmental
effects in whatever format is selected.
9) The explanation of each issue should identify:
a) the significance criteria or threshold, if any, used to evaluate each question; and
b) the mitigation measure identified, if any, to reduce the impact to less than significance.
a) Have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic
including, but not limited to, trees, rock
outcroppings, and historic buildings within a
c) Substantially degrade the existing visual
character or quality of the site and its
d) Create a new source of substantial light or
glare, which would adversely affect day or
The subject property does not affect any scenic vistas or damage any scenic resources given its
vacant nature, and will not obstruct whatever view of the mountains any properties to the south of -I-
210 freeway might have. In addition, the City of Claremont does not have any view protection
All aspects of the proposed project’s visual and design character will be subject to Architectural
Commission review and approval, in accordance with existing design criteria set forth in the
Claremont Land Use and Development Code (LUDC), prior to the commencement of any
development. The charge of the Architectural Commission will be to review the proposed
architectural design, exterior colors, materials and details, landscaping, signage and other design
features for compatibility and consistency with the City’s design review criteria, and to not approve the
development plans unless these criteria are met.
However, the proposed project may have a significant visual effect in relation to the single-family
homes located to the north of the site and the lack of development adjacent the site. The project
consists of 6 buildings with the number of units ranging from 5 to 10 in each building; the total project
will have a gross floor area of 52,000 square feet. Each unit is a two-story townhome with an
attached two-car garage. The buildings immediately adjacent Base Line Road are setback 25 feet
from the public right-of-way. While the development of the site is consistent with the General Plan,
concerns have been voiced by the community about the aesthetic and light impacts the development
will have on the area, therefore; aesthetic and lights will be analyzed in the EIR for this project.

An EIR will be completed to assess potential air quality impacts the proposed development may
create or future residents experience due to the close proximity to the I-210 Freeway and the Towne
Avenue freeway on and off ramps.
Pursuant to the recently adopted General Plan, new development following the adopted Land Use
Plan densities could result in approximately 1,185 new dwelling units citywide during the life of the
General Plan. The proposed 45-unit development is included in this number; therefore the impact of
constructing 45 new units in the proposed location was analyzed at a programmatic level within the
As stated in the General Plan Program EIR, Claremont is located within the South Coast Air Basin
(SCAB), which is comprised of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, and San Bernardino Counties. The
SCAB experiences pollutant levels that exceed state and federal air quality standards, and
occasionally reach unhealthful levels. Ozone, the primary ingredient in photochemical smog, is the
biggest pollution problem in the area. The region’s unique meteorological and climatic characteristics
are a major factor that contributes to the region’s air quality problems. However, aggressive
emissions requirements have contributed to a steady improvement in air quality. Standards for
) are not violated in Claremont. Ozone levels in the
Claremont area occasionally exceed state and federal standards, and will likely continue to do so well
century; however, there have been no first-stage smog alerts since 1995.
The SCAQMD CEQA Air Quality Handbook states that any project with daily emissions that exceed
any of the following thresholds should be considered to have an individually and cumulatively
55 lb per day of Reactive Organic Compounds (ROC)
55 lb per day of Nitrogen Oxide (NO
550 lb per day of Carbon Monoxide (CO)
150 lb per day of Inhalable Particulate Matter (PM
150 lb per day of Sulfur Oxide (SO
Short Term Construction Air Quality Impacts
The proposed project consists of the demolition of the existing ~9,000 square-foot water reservoir in
the northwest corner of the site. According to Screening Table 6-3 in the CEQA Air Quality Handbook
prepared by the South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD), the project would need to
involve more than 23 million cubic feet of building demolition and the construction of 975,000 square
feet of gross floor area to have a potentially significant air quality impact during development activities.
Based on the size of the proposed project, demolition of the 8,987 square-foot water tank and
construction of a 52,000 square-foot housing development, construction-related emissions will fall well
Nonetheless, dust generated by construction activity could have a more direct effect on surrounding
properties to the north, and to freeway traffic to the south. To reduce air quality impacts in the
immediate vicinity of the project site, grading permits will include standard requirements for the
implementation of best management practices (BMPs), such as watering the site and covering
stockpiles of dirt, in order to control fugitive dust during construction activities. Specific mitigation
measures to control fugitive dust during construction will include the following:
Standard grading permit requirements to reduce air quality impacts in the immediate vicinity of the
project site will include the implementation of best management practices (BMPs), such as watering
the site and covering stockpiles of dirt, in order to control fugitive dust during construction activities.
Pursuant to SCAQMD Rule 403, the applicant shall also be required to secure any necessary permits
from the SCAQMD, including an approved fugitive dust emissions control plan, prior to the issuance of
No mitigation measures are required for construction-related impacts beyond the standard BMPs and
SCAQMD compliance required at all construction sites.
Long-Term Operational Impacts on Air Quality
During the life of a project, emissions produced by day-to-day operations will be comprised of
stationary source emissions (primarily energy consumption) and mobile source emissions from the
vehicle trips generated by the residents of the development. The mobile and stationary source
emission factors found in Tables 9-7 and 9-8 of the CEQA Air Quality Handbook were used to
calculate the estimated emissions in the following table:
Based on the analysis summarized in the table above, operational emissions are expected to fall well

The entire Project Site is presently vacant with the I-210 Freeway to the south of the site, Base Line
Road to the north of the site and is surrounded by developed properties. As the site has been heavily
disturbed in the past and is not in its natural condition, no natural biological resources exist on the
site. The proposed project will not affect or interfere with any species, habitat, natural community,
riparian area, wetland, or migration corridor identified by any local, regional, state or federal agency.
Based on these factors no mitigation measures in the category of biological resources are necessary.
a) Cause a substantial adverse change in the
significance of a historical resource as defined
b) Cause a substantial adverse change in the
Directly or indirectly destroy a unique
paleontological resource or site or unique
d) Disturb any human remains, including those
No historic structures will be affected by the proposed project. The project site and immediate
surrounding vicinity are not recognized as an area having the potential for subsurface paleontological
or cultural resources. Since all above-ground and subsurface areas within the Project Site have been
disturbed by prior development, the likelihood for such resources is further diminished.
Since the project does not propose any subterranean levels and the site has previously been graded
to support previous agricultural uses, grading and construction activities are not expected to disturb
human remains. In the event any human remains are found during demolition or construction,
construction activities shall cease and further investigation/treatment will be followed as required by
state law. Compliance with existing regulations will ensure that no significant impact will result.

disposal systems where sewers are not

While no active earthquake faults have been confirmed within Claremont, and no Alquist-Priolo maps
have been adopted for the City, the Public Safety and Noise Element of the adopted General Plan
have identified the San Jose Fault as a potentially active fault within the City of Claremont. A
segment of the Sierra Madre fault is within very close proximity to the Project Site, as shown below.
Although all property in the City is subject to seismic activity, the Project Site may be subject to more
intense ground motion due to its proximity to a potentially active fault.
In accordance with existing local regulations, grading permits shall be required for new development
to ensure proper soil compaction and drainage. As standard procedure, grading and soil compaction
requires the preparation of specific grading plans, soils and geotechnical reports (which must address
liquefaction, subsidence, and other potential soil stability hazards), and hydrology studies which will
be reviewed and approved by the city engineer before any grading can occur. These plans will
ensure that the grading and drainage of the site will be in accordance with current engineering
In addition, according to the most recent maps prepared by the State Geologist, the subject property
is located within an area that may be susceptible to liquefaction and/or is located on expansive soil
(see figure on next page). Liquefaction-prone soils pose significant hazards to structures and
inhabitants, based on these factors and Environmental Impact Report will be completed to address
The City of Claremont does not permit the installation of new septic tanks when sewers are readily
available. The proposed project will be connected to sewer lines in the area.

An EIR will be completed to assess any potential impacts from the exposure to electromagnetic fields
(EMF’s) due to the existence of the substation to the east and the existing high voltage utility poles on
Other than typical household hazardous materials (i.e., household cleansers), the proposed project
will not involve the use or transport of hazardous materials or release hazardous materials into the
The Los Angeles Fire Department provides plan check services to ensure that adequate access is
provided to the facility. Prior to issuance of building permits by the City, the project will be subject to
review and approval by the fire department for access, fire hydrant locations, and adequate water
flow. Thereafter, the facility will be subject to periodic inspections by fire department personnel.
The project site is not located in a high fire area, and is completely surrounded by urban development
The project site is not included on the California Department of Toxic Substance Control (DTSC)
Hazardous Waste and Substances Site List (Cortese List).
The nearest airport is Cable Airport; this private airstrip is located approximately 1.9 miles to the east
of the subject property. The project site is not located in the Cable Airport land use plan clear zone.
The construction of 45 residential units on the project site will not impair implementation of or
physically interfere with an adopted emergency response plan due to the limited number of new
residences, not interfere with emergency evacuations using Base Line Road.
Figure 6-4 in the General Plan indicates that the project site is located in close proximity to a very high
fire hazard severity zone. To minimize potential fire danger the development will be required to
adhere to strict fire safety development guidelines and meet all required U.B.C. standards for fire
Based on the above analysis, no mitigation measures are required in the category of hazards and

The project site contains no surface bodies of water, springs, or areas of natural seepage. As such,
the proposed development poses no threat to the quality or flow of surface or ground waters.
Moreover, the proposed development will not require major improvements to water supply or
distribution systems that could possibly affect local water supplies. Tsunamis do not pose a hazard
due to the inland location of the site. There are no nearby lakes, reservoirs, or other closed bodies of
water that could produce a seiche during a seismic event.
Construction of the proposed building and parking areas will create impervious surfaces, and will
therefore increase the amount of surface runoff. This additional impervious surface will not create a
significant impact because the subject property has direct access to storm drain conveyances, which
have sufficient capacity to handle the added runoff to be created by the proposed project. These
conveyances include a concrete lined swale along the south property line, within the Caltrans right-of-
way, to handle the runoff that will flow to the rear of the site.
As a standard requirement for all new developments, the applicant shall be required to submit for
approval by the city engineer a comprehensive grading and drainage plan prior to the issuance of
grading and building permits. The plan shall be prepared by a registered civil engineer in
conformance with Chapter 70 of the Uniform Building Code and the City’s standard grading
requirements. The drainage plan shall demonstrate how surface water will be collected on-site and
conveyed to existing storm drain facilities.
Also, in accordance with standard City requirements, a 50-year hydrology study shall be prepared in
conformance with the standards and requirements of the Los Angeles County Flood Control District
prior to the issuance of grading permits. The study shall address how potential grading, in conjunction
with the drainage conveyance systems, will assure that the proposed development will be safe from
inundation from rainfall runoff and protect downstream properties from drainage emanating from the
The creation of impermeable surfaces also has the potential to diminish the groundwater recharge
capabilities of lands where development occurs. However, the proposed project will have an minimal
effect on usable groundwater reserves, in that the area’s usable groundwater recharge occurs within
the San Antonio Spreading Grounds, more than two miles to the northeast of the subject property.
Compliance with National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Permit
The proposed project is subject to the requirements of the L.A. County’s National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System (NPDES) permit, which includes, but is not limited to, the preparation of a Storm
Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP), and the incorporation of Best Management Practices
(BMPs) for implementation during the construction phase of the project. The following is a summary
of the NPDES requirements that must be provided as part of the routine grading permit issuance and
• The applicant is required to submit a SWPPP that incorporates BMPs for construction of the
project for review and approval by the city engineer prior to the issuance of a grading permit.
The plans shall be prepared in conjunction with the soils engineer and duly wet stamped by a
registered civil engineer with expertise in complying with NPDES permit regulations.
• The grading plan notes shall include applicable Best Management Practices (BMPs) in
accordance with National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) requirements, as
identified in the California Storm Water Best Management Practice Handbook. Copies of
BMPs and related information for land development improvement plans and construction
activity are available from the Engineering Division.
• The applicant shall sign and submit a Statement of Understanding affirming that the applicable
BMPs will be implemented to effectively minimize the negative impacts of this project’s
construction activities on the surrounding water quality. Statement of Understanding forms are
In addition to compliance with the standard NPDES requirements described above, because the
project will result in the addition of more than 5,000 square feet of impervious surfaces, the applicant
shall also comply with the following provisions of Los Angeles County’s Standard Urban Stormwater
• The SUSMP includes the requirement for infiltrating or treating the volume of stormwater runoff
from the first 0.75 inch of each storm event and of maintenance provisions for permanent Best
Management Practices (BMPs), structural or treatment controls, through such means as may
be appropriate (this could be accomplished within the proposed playground area).
• The applicant shall certify that no illicit discharges will be released from the project site to the
municipal storm drain system (gutters, streets, catch basins, storm drains, washes, flood
control channels, and other conveyances, natural or man-made, that convey runoff to receiving
• The applicant shall certify that no illicit connections (connections that convey illicit discharges to
storm drain system) shall be made.
• The applicant shall implement sediment control-type BMPs to reduce the discharge of sediment
to the municipal storm drain system. At least one type of sediment control BMP should be
used. These include silt fencing and sand bags. (Note: City may allow substitution of these
BMPs with catch basin inlet protection BMPs provided that (1) the project takes place during
the dry season; (2) no excessive sediment is discharged to the street at any time during the
project; (3) sediment discharged to the storm drain system is removed by the end of each work
Most of the City of Claremont has been developed on a foothill and along a downward slope, thus
flooding hazards are generally low. No property within the City lies within a federally designated 100-
year or 500-year flood zone. Figure 6-3 of the General Plan, San Antonio Dam Inundation, indicates
that the project site is located outside of potential dam inundation areas in the highly unlikely event the
San Antonio dam was to fail.
Based on the above analysis, and the established NPDES compliance criteria, no mitigation
measures are required in the category of hydrology and water quality.
a) Physically divide an established community?
b) Conflict with any applicable land use plan,
policy, or regulation of an agency with
jurisdiction over the project (including but not
limited to the general plan, specific plan, local
coastal program, or zoning ordinance) adopted
for the purpose of avoiding or mitigating an
c) Conflict with any applicable habitat conservation
plan or natural community conservation plan?
The project site is bordered by the I-210 Freeway on the south and Base Line Road on the north.
While there is an established single-family residential community to the north of Base Line Road, the
construction of the new multi-family housing development will not divide the community as it is located
across the street and surrounded by an Edison substation to the east and a strawberry field to the
The General Plan adopted on November 14, 2006 designates the project site for residential use with a
density of fifteen (15) units per acre. The current zoning designation for the property is RS 10,000; as
mandated by state law, the City is in the process of amending the zoning map to bring all existing
zoning citywide into conformance with the new General Plan. With the new General Plan, the zoning
on this property will be changing to RM 3,000 in the near future as part of the conformity change. The
amendment to the zoning map will modify the zoning designations of approximately 700 parcels in the
California Senate Bill 1818 went into effect on January 1, 2005; this bill allows developers who provide
affordable units to receive a density bonus. A project can receive up to a 35% density bonus if the
project provides 10 percent of the units for very-low-income, 20 percent for low-income households, or
40 percent for moderate-low-income households. The proposed project will be a 100 percent
affordable housing for very-low-income and low-income households. The Residential 15 category
allows for both attached and detached units, townhomes and condominiums. As proposed the project
will have a density of approximately 17.3 units per acre, reflective of a density bonus of 1.15 percent.
The proposed project will therefore have no impact in the category of land use planning, and no
a) Result in the loss of availability of a known
mineral resource that would be of value to the
region and the residents of the state?
b) Result in the loss of availability of a locally
delineated on a local general plan, specific plan
Figure 5-3 of the General Plan Open Space, Parkland, Conservation, Air Quality Element shows that the
subject property, together with most Claremont property south of Mt. Baldy Road and Thompson Creek
Channel, is located within an area classified by the California Division of Mines and Geology (CDMG) as
Mineral Resource Zone 2 (MRZ-2). This designation indicates that either aggregate resource exists on
the site, or that there is a high likelihood that such resources exist. However, mining activities would be
incompatible with the surrounding urban uses. Also, according to General Plan Figure 5-3, the State
Mining and Geology Board does not consider the site to be an “area of regional significance” for meeting
the region’s future mineral resource needs. Therefore, the proposed project will have no impact on the
availability of mineral resources and no mitigation measures are required in this category.

Potential noise impacts associated with the proposed housing project are related to the below listed
sources. These topics will be analyzed within the EIR.
Exposure of future residents to freeway noise
The project will result in the increase of noise during the short-term period of construction. As with all
building projects within the City, the hours of construction and noise levels associated with the
development of the site will be subject to the standards contained in Chapter 5 Part 3 of the LUDC.
Construction activities that exceed adopted noise standards area allowed to occur between the hours of
7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday excluding national holidays. Construction related
activities (i.e. deliveries, work, staging, etc) that do not violate noise standards could take place outside of
As stated in the General Plan Program EIR the subject property is exposed to roadway noise from Base
Line Road to the north and the I-210 Freeway to the south.
Base Line Road noise is not significant noise generator (63-65 decibels at the building facade) per the
General Plan Program EIR. Although the freeway is depressed as much as 30 feet below grade to
mitigate noise impacts, numerous noise complaints have been logged since its opening in November of
2002. A noise impact assessment published by Urban Crossroads in 2004 concluded that the grooved
concrete pavement of the freeway surface is the primary factor responsible for actual noise levels
exceeding estimates prior to freeway construction. There is presently no sound attenuation wall along
the rear property line of the subject parcel.
Although the City of Claremont has no power to abate transportation noise at the source, it can require
projects to incorporate soundwalls and other means of noise attenuation to buffer the project site from the
noise source. The City of Claremont succeeded in executing a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)
between the City and Caltrans District 7 in 1999, which required, among other things, Caltrans to
construct soundwalls along the I-210 Freeway right-of-way prior to construction of the freeway. Pursuant
to the 1999 MOU, Caltrans constructed 12-foot or taller soundwalls along the segments of the I-210
Freeway abutting residential properties, as well as the nearby Montessori school at 560 Base Line Road.
Caltrans did not provide soundwalls adjacent to office or retail uses, or adjacent to commercially zoned
vacant parcels, or vacant land such as the subject property.
The General Plan EIR conducted a noise analysis on all areas in the City. The subject parcel presently
lies within a noise contour of 70 dBA. This site is projected to continue to experience noise at this level in
the future as documented in Figures 6-6 and 6-8 of the General Plan. Table 6-5 of the General Plan
established maximum exterior noise levels of 70 dBA for medium density multiple family land uses. A
noise impact analysis will be conducted as part of the EIR to determine the specific steps that need to be
taken to reduce the interior and exterior decibels experienced on the site.
The site is adequately separated from the nearby general aviation airport (Brackett and Cable) so that
persons residing within the new residential units will not be exposed to excessive noise levels from
a) Induce substantial population growth in an area,
either directly (for example, by proposing new
example, through extension of road or other
c) Displace substantial numbers of people,
The proposed development was anticipated by the General Plan in terms of population and housing.
The General Plan, adopted November 14, 2006, addresses the need for additional affordable housing
in the City of Claremont, specifically low-income housing at the subject site. The proposal is
consistent with the intent and policies of the General Plan, providing 45 low income units.
The proposed location for the new housing development is on vacant land and will not result in the
displacement of people. While the new development will provide additional housing in the area, the
addition of 45 units will not result in a substantial population growth in the area. The City of Claremont
has an average family size of 3.08 persons and an average household size of 2.56 persons (2000
Census). The proposal will result in an addition of approximately 115-138 residents, depending on
which average size is used (~0.003 population increase). This population increase has been
analyzed within the General Plan EIR and is minimal.
No mitigation measures are required in the category of population and housing.

times or other performance objectives for any of
The proposed use may have an impact on the availability of quality of public services such as police
protection and parks. An environmental impact report will address the potential impacts and provide
mitigation measures in these areas where necessary.
The development of the proposed 45-unit housing development will not have an impact on Fire
Protection. The City of Claremont contracts with the Consolidated Fire Protection District of Los
Angeles County for both emergency prevention and response services. Three County fire stations
are located in Claremont - Station 62 at 3710 Mills Avenue, Station 101 at 606 West Bonita and
Station 102 at 4370 Sumner Avenue. All new development is required to receive approval from the
LACFD to ensure that adequate fire protection can be provided. The development is subject to review
by the Fire Protection District to ensure the project meets all requirements for fire access to the site in
The project will have little impact on local public schools. According to the Program EIR for the
Claremont General Plan the Claremont Unified School District (CUSD) has a student generation rate
of 0.4 students per household. Based on the proposed 45 units, it is estimated the project will
generate 18 students, which will cause a limited impact on local schools.

The proposed 45-unit housing development will not increase the use of existing neighborhood and
regional parks or other recreational facilities such that substantial physical deterioration will occur. The
City of Claremont has an average family size of 3.08 persons and an average household size of 2.56
persons (2000 Census). The proposal will result in an addition of approximately 115-138 residents,
depending on which average size is used. This population has been analyzed within the General
The project will provide recreation facilities on site for the residents; these facilities include a
recreational room, pool, sports court and tot lot, along with open space area. These new facilities will
not have an adverse physical effect on the environment. In addition to on-site facilities, nearby
recreational facilities such as the Thompson Creek Trail (accessed on Towne Avenue), and Griffith
Park, are within walking distance from the site. Due to previous public, comment this issue will be
reviewed as part of public services in the EIR.

Traffic impacts associated with the proposed housing project will be analyzed within the EIR on the
Updated traffic counts within the Project study area;
Analysis of the Towne Avenue/Base Line Road intersection;
Access into and out of the proposed development on to Base Line Road; and
Other factors as deemed warranted during the public scoping process and based on the expertise
A vehicle trip is defined as a single or one-direction vehicle movement, with either the origin or the
destination (exiting or entering) inside a study site. Street system operating conditions are typically
described in terms of “Level of Service” (LOS). LOS is a report card type scale used to indicate the
quality of traffic flow on roadway segments and at intersections. Levels of Service range from A (free
flow, little congestion) to F (forced flow, extreme congestion).
The Circulation Element of the General Plan, contains a policy to allow new development only if the
resulting levels of service on affected major arterials do not fall below a daily LOS D and a peak hour
LOS E. Table 5.30 of the General Plan EIR analyzes the LOS for the Towne Avenue/Base Line Road
intersection. Currently the intersection has an existing LOS of “C”, and with the future build out of the
estimated 1,185 dwelling units, the General Plan EIR anticipates that the LOS at this intersection will
remain at LOS“C”. The ITE Trip Generation manual (7
Edition) provides a Weekday a.m. and p.m.
Peak Hour Generator of 0.73 trips per day for rental townhomes. Therefore, the 45 unit development
will have an estimated 33 a.m. and p.m. peak trips.
Each unit will have an attached two car garage and 12 uncovered parking spaces will be provided on
the site, a total of 102 spaces. The State Density Bonus Law imposes parking standards that allow
developers to provide fewer parking spaces than required by City code. These standards require 1
parking space for 0-1 bedroom units, 2 parking spaces for 2-3 bedroom units and 2.5 parking spaces
for units with 4 or more bedrooms. The project provides state parking requirements.
There will be no impact on air traffic patterns from this project and the development does not conflict
with programs supporting alternative transportation. The project is required to obtain approval from
the Los Angeles County Fire Department and Claremont Police Department to ensure adequate
emergency access on site is provided and maintained.

The proposal will have a minimal impact on the above-referenced utilities and service systems, and
water supply impacts fall below the thresholds established by SB 610 and 221, state thresholds
multiplies by the number of units. The General Plan EIR addresses the water supply for the City of
Claremont as part of the General Plan EIR, Golden State Water confirmed that adequate supply will
be available to support planned land uses as outlined by the land use plan, including this proposed
All utilities are already present in the area to serve the project site, and there is sufficient capacity (or
there will be) to accommodate the needs of the proposed project. Existing regulations require new
development to connect to these services. As part of the permitting process for grading and on-site
improvements, the project proponent is required to submit to the city engineer hydrology and sewer
capacity studies to determine if upgrades or modifications to existing conveyances are necessary to
As a standard requirement for all new developments, the cumulative impacts of the project on
drainage and sanitation facilities will be addressed through the assessment of drainage and sewer
facility fees. The fees are required by the City and the Los Angeles County Sanitation District to fund
needed improvements to the City’s storm drain and sewer systems to reduce the cumulative impacts
caused by new development, and are apportioned to new development based on the new
development’s fair share of the estimated costs of the improvements.
The solid waste generated by the demolition and construction activities at the project site, will
generate solid waste such as scrap wood and metal, drywall, cement, asphalt, etc. As with all
construction projects, the applicant will be responsible for collecting and properly disposing of waste
materials. The Building Division and Community Services Department routinely work with developers
to coordinate the recycling and export of demolition salvage, and the proper disposal of non-

Based on the analysis and substantiations provided in this Initial Study, a reasonable argument can
be made that the proposed project may have a significant effect on the environment or impact future
residents of the project in certain issue areas. Therefore, pursuant to Section 15065 of the CEQA
Guidelines, a focused Environmental Impact Report shall be prepared to more fully examine potential
environmental impacts in the following categories:
